awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research - Enabling Transfer Students Access to Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program supports the retention and graduation of high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need.  This project, at Allan Hancock College, Cuesta College, and California Polytechnic State University (Cal Poly) will fund fifty 2-year scholarships at Allan Hancock and fifty 2-year scholarships at Cuesta College.  The Scholars will be in cohorts of 25 students who are pursuing transfer to a BS-granting institution to study engineering. This project will also fund sixty-two scholarships at Cal Poly for transfer students from Allan Hancock and Cuesta, thus supporting the Scholars until their graduation with a BS degree in engineering. Allan Hancock and Cuesta are highly-ranked Hispanic-Serving Institutions. Cal Poly is one of only five comprehensive polytechnic universities in the nation, and is ranked as a one of the nation's top public masters-level institutions. This project will build on and strengthen collaborations to increase the number of low-income students who begin their engineering education at Allan Hancock or Cuesta, transfer to Cal Poly, are retained in and graduate with a BS degree, and enter a STEM graduate program or the STEM workforce.

Specific program activities seek to remove or minimize economic barriers and support student development in five areas: 1) academic; 2) engineering transfer/career path; 3) personal, via Strengths and Growth Mindset training from a Social Justice perspective; 4) connection; and 5) professional. The project will also adopt essential evidence-based transfer practices, continuously assessing progress achieved in this area within and across each participating campus to institutionalize more robust transfer pathways and support the success of all future STEM transfer students at Allan Hancock, Cuesta, and Cal Poly.  The project will include two research strands designed to advance understanding of strategies that enhance transfer student success in a career in engineering.  The first research project will use social network analysis, survey methods, and qualitative interviews to advance understanding of how project activities contribute to a) growth of student social networks; b) increase in student resilience, confidence, sense of community, and sense of belonging; and c) whether growth in these areas is related to increased student retention, pre-transfer success, transfer, and post-transfer success. The second research project will integrate pre- and post-transfer Scholars into existing research to advance understanding of student motivations and perceptions when choosing to participate in (or leave) co-curricular team projects in engineering. The integration of Scholars allows for investigation of whether decision-making factors regarding participation in co-curricular team projects are consistent for student groups at community colleges and four-year institutions, and for students who are directly admitted or transfer to a 4-year institution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: ALLAN HANCOCK JOINT COMMUNITY COLLEGE DISTRICT

por.por_cntn:
Enabling Transfer Students Access to Engineering at Allan Hancock College in Santa Maria, CA (NSF Award No. 1834154) is a collaborative project with Cuesta College and California Polytechnic University San Luis Obispo (NSF Award No. 1835128), both in San Luis Obispo, CA. The project was locally called ENGAGE – Engineering Neighbors: Gaining Access, Growing Engineers. Cal Poly SLO (CPSLO) is a highly-ranked comprehensive public university with extremely competitive applicant pools for both first-time freshman and transfer students. Allan Hancock College (AHC) and Cuesta College are nearby California community colleges; many AHC and Cuesta engineering and computer science students desire to transfer to CPSLO because of its high-quality programs and proximity to the two colleges.

ENGAGE is a scholarship and mentorship project with the following goals:

  • Increase retention and success rates, and transfer and graduation numbers, of low-income academically-talented students with demonstrated financial need who begin their engineering or computer science education at AHC or Cuesta, intend to transfer to CPSLO, graduate with a bachelor’s of science degree, and enter the STEM workforce or a graduate program.
  • Advance the understanding of strategies that affect recruitment, retention, transfer, academic success, academic/career pathways, degree attainment, and entry into the STEM workforce or graduate programs, with a specific emphasis on low-income academically-talented students with demonstrated financial need who begin their engineering or computer science education at a community college.
  • Contribute to the implementation and effective evidence-based curricular and co-curricular activities for low-income, underrepresented, and academically-talented engineering or computer science students.

The AHC ENGAGE project supported 64 scholars in four cohorts from academic year 2019–20 through 2023–24. Of the 64 scholars, 48 (75%) were from underrepresented ethnic/racial minority populations. Forty-four awardees (69%) have transferred to a four-year university as of Fall 2024: 32 to CPSLO, and 12 to other universities. Three more scholars are on track to transfer in Fall 2025, for a total of 47 transfers and an overall project transfer rate of 73%.

Scholarships were provided to AHC scholars at up to $9,000 per year, or up to their unmet financial need, whichever was less. The financial support allowed scholars to reduce their work hours, enabling them to focus on their studies, and participate in campus activities as full-time students. ENGAGE scholars built strong academic foundations and were very competitive in CPSLO transfer applicants; ENGAGE transfer acceptance rates to CPSLO exceeded non-ENGAGE transfer applicants by a significant margin.

Just as important, the ENGAGE collaboration – AHC, Cuesta, and CPSLO – supported scholars to develop as students and people. Programming was designed (and continuously evaluated and updated) to increase “transfer student capital” to enable scholars to excel at their transfer institution. The project supported students in five areas: (1) academics, via tutorial support; (2) transfer and career path identification, via counselors, mentors and workshops; (3) personal development, via Clifton Strengths and growth-mindset trainings using a culturally-informed approach; (4) network building within the community college and with Cal Poly, via cohort meetings, mentors and Cal Poly field trips; and (5) professional development and engineering/computer science identity building, via mentors and workshops. These growth opportunities are critical. Not only are AHC ENGAGE scholars preparing to transfer, but most are first-generation college students looking for guidance and to gain a sense of belonging.

Each scholar was assigned two faculty mentors – one at AHC and one at CPSLO. This dual mentorship enabled students to learn more about their pathway, to better navigate the community college, and to connect with – and feel a part of – the university at least one year before they applied for transfer. 

The ENGAGE collaboration has been a true partnership between the two community colleges and the four-year university. Each step in the project was jointly executed – from proposal writing, to recruitment, to event planning, to implementation, to evaluation, and to dissemination. Students felt the authenticity of the partnership and experienced real bridges to support them on their journeys. The project team has learned how to create and sustain partnerships between community colleges and B.S.-granting institutions, while at the same time supporting students holistically.

The project shared its learnings and best practices with various national and regional audiences via papers, presentations, and workshops. Project dissemination has occurred at: the American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) annual conference; the National Institute for the Study of Transfer Students (NISTS) conference; the University of New Mexico Mentoring Institute annual conference; the Chronicle of Mentoring & Coaching; the Frontiers in Education annual conference; ASEE’s Pacific Southwest Section annual conference; California State University’s CSU-LSAMP Alliance annual meeting; and the California Engineering Liaison Council meetings.


Last Modified: 01/29/2025
Modified by: Dominic J Dal Bello
